author: Robyn Ironside
title: Malaysia Airlines moving on after tragic 2014
text:
Video Image France: MH370 search operation continues over Reunion Island 0:40 The search for the wreckage of Malaysia Airlines flight MH370 continued around Reunion Island in the Indian Ocean, Tuesday. French FAZSOI (Armed Forces of the South Indian Ocean) crew members scanned the Indian Ocean for the wreckage. Three boats are also at the search party's disposal, but local government sources stated that Navy units would only be mobilised if debris is found at sea. The Malaysia Airlines flight MH370 went missing over the South China Sea on March 8 2014, with 239 passengers and crew on board, whilst flying from Kuala Lumpur International Airport to Beijing Capital International Airport. In late July, 2015, a wing of a plane was found on Reunion Island, which Malaysian Prime Minister Najib Razak later confirmed to be part of the missing Boeing 777 aircraft. Since then search parties have been going out on a regular basis in an effort to find the rest of the wreckage.
August 12th 2015 2 months ago /video/video.news.com.au/News/World/ Christoph Mueller, Malaysia Airlines' CEO at the airline's Kuala Lumpur headquarters
Robyn Ironside News Corp Australia Network IT is nerve wracking enough having a boarding pass with the letters MH in front of the flight number without being seated next to the passenger from hell.
Malaysia Airlines has had to deal with a lot in the past 18 months and at times during the trip from Kuala Lumpur to Sydney there was a sense the frazzled crew could not cope with any more.
The flight over to KL was relatively uneventful in comparison.
A sudden shutdown of the In Flight Entertainment centre an hour before landing gave twitchy passengers a start — it’s not what you want on an airline with an aircraft still missing after all communications were lost.
But it was an otherwise unremarkable experience.
Returning to Australia was much different thanks to the passenger across the aisle, in the front row of Business Class.
Back in the day ... Business Class suites when they were installed in 2005. Ten years later they are in need of a refresh. Picture: Supplied Source: News Corp Australia
Minutes into the flight the shirt came off.
It’s not a crime to travel in a singlet, tatts on display but perhaps it should be.
Then the drinking started. He wasn’t happy with the reluctant drinks service and made it well known.
His displeasure was duly noted by crew who seemed to decide it was easier to ignore responsible service standards, even after his travelling companion announced to the entire cabin “I’ve never drunk so much in my life” followed by “I’ve never been so drunk”.
With her indisposed, the man amused himself making derogatory remakes about the flight attendant’s weight to the growing discomfort of other passengers.
In-training. Malaysia Airlines' flight attendants learning how to work on an A330 at the carrier’s training facility in Kuala Lumpur. Picture: Supplied Source: Supplied
Crew clearly didn’t know how to handle such a person and simply avoided any contact, making for a miserable experience for those seated nearby.
Once considered one of the world’s best full service carriers, Malaysia is now a long way from competitors such as Singapore Airlines, Qantas, Etihad and Emirates.
The aircraft interiors are tired, budgets are obviously tight, and crews lacking in energy, enthusiasm, and possibly training in handling difficult passengers.
While Malaysia Airlines does not have the money of Emirates and Etihad, crew should perhaps know that a smile, a genuine interest in passengers and pride in one’s work costs nothing.
Their food is certainly something to be proud of.
Service highlight ... the food in Malaysia Airlines’ Business Class is up there with the best. Picture: Supplied Source: Supplied
The beef and chicken satay sticks served in Business and First Class are the only ones in the world pre-cooked over charcoal before being served at 40,000 feet.
Servings are generous and tasty and come with beverages of the passenger’s choice.
Seats in Business lie almost flat but the incline had me sliding towards the footrest.
CEO Christoph Mueller is working on the many challenges facing Malaysia in the wake of the twin tragedies of MH370 and MH17, and the airline’s near financial collapse.
He has promised significant changes to cabin interiors including the seats, in-flight entertainment and flight crew uniform.
Mueller has even reconsidered his original plan to have no union representation for employees, having had difficult experiences in the past.
There is no doubt he faces an enormous challenge and the changes to be unveiled in coming months will be critical to not only attracting passengers but ensuring they want to return.
Robyn Ironside flew as a guest of Malaysia Airlines.
